description: The patriarch of the Hebrew people, known as 'Father Abraham' for being the ancestor of the Israelites. God establishes a covenant with him, and his resilient faith sets the pattern for righteousness in Israelite religion.

The reluctant savior of Israel who leads the exodus from Egypt. He mediates between God and the people, transforming the Israelites into a nation founded on religious laws. Known for his miracles and his unique relationship with God.

The king of Israel and founder of Jerusalem. His reign marks the high point of Israel's history. He unifies religious and political life by bringing the Ark of the Covenant to Jerusalem and is known for his political shrewdness and forgiveness.

The grandson of Abraham and father of the twelve tribes of Israel. His life is marked by deception and struggle, including wrestling with God. His name, 'Israel,' means 'struggles with God,' reflecting the nation's tumultuous history.
Jacob’s son who rises to power in Egypt after being sold into slavery by his brothers. He saves his family from famine and exemplifies forgiveness and redemption.
Israel’s first king, chosen by God but later rejected due to religious errors. His inner turmoil and tragic downfall contrast with David’s mercy and success.

David’s son and the third king of Israel. Known for his wisdom, wealth, and building the Temple in Jerusalem. His later years are marked by idolatry due to his foreign wives, leading to Israel’s decline.
A prophet who opposes the worship of Baal in Israel. Known for his miracles and confrontation with King Ahab and Jezebel, he represents a spiritual hero before Israel’s exile.
Elijah’s successor as a prophet. Continues Elijah’s mission against idolatry and performs miracles, but Israel’s decline persists.
The first man created by God. His disobedience in eating the forbidden fruit introduces sin into the world.
The first woman created by God. She shares in Adam’s disobedience, leading to the fall of humanity.
The survivor of God’s great flood. He builds the ark to save humanity and animals, representing the first covenant between God and humanity.
Abraham’s son and the second patriarch of Israel. His life is marked by being acted upon, such as when God tests Abraham by commanding him to sacrifice Isaac.
Moses’s brother and the first high priest of Israel. He assists Moses in leading the Israelites out of Egypt and often mediates between Moses and the people.
Moses’s successor who leads the Israelites into the Promised Land. He directs the military conquest and exhorts Israel to remain faithful to God.
A judge of Israel known for his superhuman strength. His life is marked by rash decisions and conflicts with the Philistines, but his strength comes from his devotion to God.
The last judge of Israel and the prophet who anoints Saul and David as kings. He serves as a spiritual leader and ushers in the monarchy.
David’s son who attempts to overthrow his father’s throne. His rebellion represents internal corruption in Israel.
David’s loyal military commander. He contrasts with David by seeking justice and retribution against traitors.
Solomon’s son whose harsh policies lead to the division of Israel into the northern and southern kingdoms.
The first king of the northern kingdom of Israel. He establishes idol worship, leading to religious corruption.
A wicked king of Israel who promotes the worship of Baal. His reign is marked by conflict with the prophet Elijah.
Ahab’s wife who spreads the worship of Baal in Israel. Her death fulfills Elijah’s prophecy of divine judgment.
A Jewish queen of Persia who saves her people from extermination through her courage and cunning.
A righteous man tested by God and Satan. He questions suffering but remains faithful, refusing to curse God.
